title: Macron says Netanyahu 'mustn't forget his country was created by a UN decision'
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who told Macron he is 'opposed' to a ceasefire in Lebanon, hit back at the French president's comments, saying the country's founding was achieved by the 1948 Arab-Israeli war. Meanwhile, Hezbollah's deputy leader Naim Qassem said the only solution was a ceasefire while threatening to expand the scope of its missile strikes across Israel.

title: US warns Israel that aid could be withheld as Netanyahu vows 'no ceasefire' in Lebanon
summary: President Joe Biden has repeatedly voiced concern about the lack of assistance and high civilian casualties but only once is known to have blocked a shipment in the billions of dollars of US aid to Israel.

title: Mbappé's lawyer says footballer to take legal action for libel over rape claims
summary: According to Swedish media, an investigation has been opened against the player for rape and sexual assault in Stockholm.

title: After 100 days of Labour government, where's the hope?
summary: A series of missteps has dented British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's political capital, and he is about to present a likely 'painful' budget.

title: Harris works to energize Black male voters as Trump supports 'stop and frisk'
summary: Both Harris and Trump are trying to energize key constituencies that allies worry may be slipping away in a razor-tight race with just 21 days left until the election.

title: In Poland, vodka sold in fruity pouches resembling children's purées causes a scandal
summary: A range of alcoholic products sold in packaging similar to popular children's purées has reignited the debate on alcohol sales restrictions.

title: In Saint Petersburg, dissidents resist on tiptoe
summary: Despite the political repression that has intensified since the war in Ukraine, Russian citizens opposed to Vladimir Putin's regime are not giving up. But to avoid arrest, they have no choice but to act quietly.

title: Japan's new 10,000 Yen banknote rankles with newlyweds
summary: The new banknote, in circulation since July, features the face of Shibusawa Eiichi, an industrialist regarded as the 'father of Japanese capitalism,' but also known for his infidelity and boorishness.

title: Sub-Saharan Africa 'trapped' by insufficient growth
summary: The region's economic recovery continues to 'lag' behind the rest of the world, according to the World Bank, which advocates greater investment in education.

title: 'L'Histoire de Souleymane': Two days of pure suspense in the life of a migrant
summary: Boris Lojkine's film follows an undocumented migrant from Guinea, brilliantly played by Abou Sangare, waiting for his legal status to be granted in France.

title: 'L'Histoire de Souleymane' wasn't meant to be a 'politically correct film,' director says
summary: Boris Lojkine, who holds a degree in philosophy, sought to shake up the codes of French cinema, both in the stories he tells and in the way he works.

title: 'The US presidential campaign resembles an unfunded quest for a lost paradise'
summary: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are proposing increased spending as if deficits didn't matter. Despite the US not being at war or in recession, the federal government is borrowing heavily, writes Le Monde columnist Stéphane Lauer.

title: Italy's Meloni to visit Lebanon Friday after hits on UN peacekeepers
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni would be the first head of state or government to visit Lebanon since escalations between Israel and Lebanese militant group Hezbollah in September.

title: China steps up pressure on Taiwan as military drills prepare for potential invasion
summary: The government of the island, which Beijing considers one of its provinces, announced on Tuesday that it had detected a record 153 Chinese aircraft in one day near its territory.

title: Italy sends first group of asylum seekers to Albania
summary: The migrants rescued in the Mediterranean by an Italian ship are scheduled to be disembarked in Albania on Wednesday. However, the legal and logistical viability of this project, proposed by Giorgia Meloni, remains uncertain.

title: 'I don't feel I've committed the slightest irregularity,' Le Pen tells court at party's fake jobs trial
summary: The former president of the Rassemblement National and former Member of the European Parliament is facing charges of 'misappropriation of public funds.' She is appearing before the Paris Criminal Court from Monday, October 14 to Wednesday, October 16.

title: Paris' Musée du Quai Branly reveals the legend of the Haitian undead
summary: The Parisian museum devotes a rich exhibition to the history of zombification practices on the Caribbean island with 'Zombies: Death is not the end?'

title: Ubisoft staff in France strike over home working
summary: The strike was sparked by a September message from management insisting on a return to three days working in the office for all staff worldwide.

title: Ukraine's war-torn parliament: A symbol of resistance that's become 'a very depressing place'
summary: Under martial law, there are no elections in sight in Ukraine. Exhausted, lawmakers, whose mandates have expired, must remain in office until the end of the war. Many want to resign.

title: Space start-ups must convince investors of the viability of existing projects
summary: Over the past two years, financing for new space start-ups has leveled off in France and worldwide.

title: Philippe Charlier, curator of the exhibition 'Zombies: Is Death Not an End?': 'The zombie is a very relevant figure today'
summary: In an interview with 'Le Monde,' the anthropologist, archaeologist and physician explains his role as chief curator of the exhibition 'Zombies: Is Death Not an End?' at the Musée du Quai Branly-Jacques-Chirac in Paris.

title: Japan warns against 'escalation' on Korean peninsula
summary: The North blew up the roads and railways on Tuesday, Seoul's military said, adding it had conducted a 'counter-fire' operation in response.

title: Fossil fuels: Is a decrease in demand really in sight?
summary: As the International Energy Agency prepares to publish its annual report on Wednesday, producer countries are calling its forecasts for declining consumption of coal, oil and gas by 2030 a 'fantasy.'
